Fujitsu (headquarters: Kizu city), which handles the installation of electronic components and the manufacture and sale of machinery, has entered the field of developing systems to prevent "leaving behind" children and others in cars.
A car equipped with a sensor that detects human presence and sends a notification to the phone or chat when it senses movement.
Currently, we are conducting a proof of concept using our own vehicles.
Keeping your child safe during a painful accident.
Currently, two vehicles are being used to transport children to the after-school English conversation school "teracoya THANK" that the company operates in Kizu City, and a trial is being conducted.
Three people sensors, which detect movement by the difference in temperature between a person and their surroundings, were installed in the car's ceiling.
If the engine is off and the door is closed for a certain period of time, the system will automatically send a warning if it detects movement of a person.
By linking the state and information of the engine and door, it can prevent false alarms as much as possible.
The warning was issued through the cloud.
You can call the number you have registered in advance, or display it on your computer or smartphone chat.
You can register multiple addresses and consider ways to prevent mistakes like missing deliveries.
The trial will continue until the end of February.

Mr. Kamiya Ichikou, the chief of the second section of the Innovation Promotion Department, pointed out, "During the experiment, we were able to see the surrounding issues that were not part of the system."
For example, a driver could be given an environment where they can focus on driving, and pick up a variety of issues related to school buses.
"Expand the solution" and put all your strength into it.
The reason for the development of a system to prevent abandonment was an abandonment accident that occurred in a series of reception bases throughout the country.
A suggestion was made to employees with young children about what they could do to ensure their children's safety.
We decided to develop a system that utilizes the know-how we have gained through our factory automation business, such as IoT (Internet of Things) and information management using sensors.
Fujis disposal prevention system is selling on ease.
The sensor can be installed just by sticking it to the ceiling.
Since it can easily be added to a taxi, we will lower the hurdle for introduction and aim for widespread use.
In the future, we will consider productization, with the cooperation of daycare centers and kindergartens.

The Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism has set a target to reduce greenhouse gas emissions from airports by 46% or more (compared to 13 years ago) by 2050, in order to achieve carbon neutrality.
The council held its first meeting in November last year to receive the plan, and aims to precede the planning of other six airports in the prefecture.
The second meeting will be non-public, as with the first.
According to the chairman, who responded to the interview after the meeting, the meeting confirmed the amount of greenhouse gas emissions from the same airport.
We have been working on a consensus that follows the guidelines of the Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism, aiming at goal setting and the introduction of renewable energy.
According to the distributed materials, the CO2 emission of the facilities and vehicles at the airport in the base year of 2013 was 1,476 tons (excluding aircraft).

Among them, the lighting and air conditioning of the terminal building at the airport and 7 other facilities account for about 1,321 tons, or about 90 percent, followed by 84 tons of aviation lighting and 71 tons of airport vehicle.
In the committee, they discuss the reduction of emissions from these facilities and vehicles.
"Now is the time for passage. The committee members are in agreement, and first, I want to make sure that the summary of the interim report is done properly," said Ando.
In the future, the third meeting will be used for the mid-term report, the fourth meeting for the final report, and opinions will be heard, and a promotion plan will be formulated.
"Sakasama" Real Estate Office Opens on Island to Attract People to Live There | Society and Economy | Nihon Shimbun
Opening event to deepen understanding of "sakasama immovable property" = 8th, famous town

The opening event of the Sakasama Fudosan branch office of the real estate website service "Sakasama Fudosan" that aims to visualize the thoughts of people who want to try renting empty houses or shops, was held on the 8th at the famous town famous community "entaku".
The operator explains the service in the talk session.

Takigono (Hokkaido, Shiranuka-gun) branch manager, Daisuke Kobayashi, said, "If we can create a movement and flow by doing this in the Oga Peninsula, then we can attract people to the island as a whole."

Sakasama immovable property is the opposite of normal immovable property. The owner of the property discloses information to those who want to borrow it and contacts the lender to reach an agreement, and if they agree, they contract individually.
As a real-world experiment to discover hidden vacant houses and establish relationships through vacant houses, On―Co Co., Ltd. (Headquarters: Mie Prefecture) began services in June 2020.
This is the seventh branch office to be opened in Kyushu, the first in the region.
It's the first time in the country, and the first time in the island.
About 20 people, including On-Co and Tugino staff, hotel staff, employees of the town offices of both towns, and local residents, participated in the event.

The representative director of Dai-Ichi Bank in Okinawa said, "I thought that if we can make use of empty houses and shops, the town will grow more if we bring in people from outside the island," explaining the background of the branch office opening.
"I want to help those who have something on the island or want to do something, even if it's just one person, in their efforts," he said.

Representative Watanabe Takashi of On-Co said, "We need to discuss how to use each empty house, what the local people want to do with this area, what kind of people they want to bring in, and what criteria they will use to make their decisions."
"The more connected people are, the more information they will receive," he told islanders, urging them to participate in discussions and share information.
